--- title: "Arguments" format: html: toc: false section-divs: true include-after-body: - text: | engine: knitr filters: - webr webr: cell-options: editor-font-scale: 0.85 fig-width: 6 fig-height: 3.7 out-width: "70%" --- ### Arguments {.no-hide} Watch [this video](https://vimeo.com/220490157): ```{=html}
``` ### `args()` `rnorm()` is a function that generates random variables from a normal distribution. Find the arguments of `rnorm()` using the `args()` function. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r args(rnorm) ``` ::: ### Good job! `n` specifies the number of random normal variables to generate. `mean` and `sd` describe the distribution to generate the random values with. ### Optional arguments ::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon=false .question} **Which arguments of `rnorm()` are not optional?** ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}



``` ::: ::: ::: ### `rnorm()` Use `rnrom()` to generate 100 random normal values with a mean of 100 and a standard deviation of 15. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} ``` ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r rnorm(100, mean = 100, sd = 15) ``` ::: ### `rnorm()` 2 Can you spot the error in the code below? Fix the code and then re-run it. ::: {.panel-tabset} ## {{< fa code >}} Interactive editor ```{webr-r} rnorm(100, mu = 100, sd = 15) ``` ## {{< fa lightbulb >}} Hint **Hint:** In math, $\mu$ (mu, pronounced "mew" or "moo") is a Greek letter that stands for the mean of a distribution. ## {{< fa circle-check >}} Solution ```r rnorm(100, mean = 100, sd = 15) ``` ::: ##
